The results of ICP-OES, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM-EDX, Raman and DR-Uv-vis spectra indicate that well-dispersed Cr and V sites in isolated state were the main species. Bimodal ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene/high-density polyethylene in-reactor blends (UHMWPE/HDPE IRBs) could be synthesized with polymerization activity ＞ 1×107 gPE·mol−1Cr·h−1. Moreover, the two catalysts displayed similar catalytic behaviors in temperature sensitivity, H2 response and 1-hexene copolymerization efficiency, and their polymer products also show comparable molecular weight and molecular weight distribution, which implies analogous structures of their well-dispersed active sites. By contrast, the catalyst prepared by wet-impregnation process with water as solvent exhibited poor dispersity, which is reflected by its much lower activity and very different catalytic behaviors and polymer properties when compared with the well-dispersed catalysts. Therefore, the economic and green solvent-free process is promising for preparing highly-active CrOx/VOx/TiO2-SiO2. Typically, this catalyst can be prepared by the following three steps: (1) Impregnating silica support with the solution of Cr source; (2) Drying the Cr source/silica mixture; (3) Calcinating the dried Cr source/silica mixture between 300 and 900 °C under the atmosphere of oxygen or dry air to get Cr(VI)Ox/silica [3]. Though the preparation process is simple, it receives more concerns from environmental safety in the past decades, as Cr(VI) is defined as a kind of highly toxic and carcinogenic substance for human and has a risk to pollute the environment via industrial liquid wastes [4]. Therefore, Cr(VI) source such as CrO3, which was often used in the past, is replaced by some low-valent Cr compounds such as Cr(III) acetate and nitrate [1,5]. However, recent studies also indicates that the status of Cr(III) is also under question [6]. Its toxicity to some plants and worms were disclosed [7–9], and large dose of Cr(III) also poses a threat to the health of human and animals [10], while the formation of Cr(VI) via Cr(III) oxidation in soils and groundwater also catches much attentions [11]. Nevertheless, removing Cr(VI) and Cr(III) from industrial waste liquid is a mandatory and challenging task up to now [12,13]. Meanwhile, on the basis of the Phillips catalyst, a novel bimetallic catalyst CrOx/VOx/silica was recently developed by our group, which shows great potential for one pot synthesis of bimodal ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene/high-density polyethylene in-reactor blends (UHMWPE/HDPE IRBs) with excellent properties [14,15]. Likewise, owing to almost the same preparation process as to the Phillips catalyst, as well as the hazardous effects of vanadium for human and environmental healthy [16], similar environmental problems are also confronted by this catalyst. In this context, developing a solvent-free route for CrOx/VOx/silica preparation is a possible way to alleviate this problem, as it not only avoids the generation of Cr/V containing liquid waste, but also makes the process simpler and more economic. Herein, it is timely to recall that surface migration of metal sites induced by pretreatment, reactants and reaction conditions has been widely revealed for many heterogeneous catalysis systems [17–19]. With regard to the Phillips catalyst, Hogen and later Weckhuysen et al. found that, when physical mixing CrOx/silica with supports such as SiO2, Al2O3 and TiO2, the Cr species could migrate between different supports, indicating their excellent surface migration as well [20–23]. McDaniel et al. proposed the migration worked via a dynamic hydrolysis mechanism between Cr and surface hydroxyl groups [24,25]. In addition, the volatile nature of Cr(VI) at high temperature should also be considered [26,27]. Similarly, Wachs et al. also observed surface migration behaviors of VOx species on SnO2 and TiO2. It is likely owing to the low melting and Tammann temperature of VOx, which makes it diffuse on support surface easily [28–30]. All in all, it means both CrOx and VOx show good surface mobility and preparing CrOx/VOx/silica in the absence of solvent is possible. However, it is not known how well Cr and V can be dispersed on support in the absence of solvent, while site dispersity is often proposed to play a significant role for polyolefin catalysts [31,32]. More importantly, it is also unclear whether catalytic behaviors and polymer properties of the catalyst would be altered or not when compared with the cases in which conventional solvent process is employed. Therefore, in this contribution, an attempt was made to prepare this bimetallic catalyst by directly dry mixing Cr and V source with supports and subsequent calcination. Meanwhile, it was disclosed that, CrOx and VOx showed higher mobility on the surface of other metal oxides such as TiO2 and Al2O3 when compared with SiO2 [20,21,30]. TiO2 modification was also reported to promote the performance of both CrOx/SiO2 and VOx/SiO2 for ethylene polymerization [33–38]. Hence, instead of pure SiO2 support, TiO2 modified SiO2 (TiO2-SiO2) was used as support to prepare CrOx/VOx/TiO2-SiO2 in this work. Furthermore, with water and ethanol as solvent, catalysts prepared by conventional wetness impregnation were used for comparison. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Raw materials SiO2 with the brand name as SH-3 was kindly donated by Ecovyst. Ti(OBu)4 (99%), Cr(III) acetylacetonate (Cr(acac)3, 99.9%), vanadyl (IV) acetylacetonate (VO(acac)2, 98%) and 1-hexene (99%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical. Tri-isobutyl aluminum (TiBA, 1 M solution of hexane) was purchased from Tosoh. Ethanol and n-hexane were supplied by Baishi Chemical. High purity H2, N2, dry air and polymerization grade C2H4 were purchased from GQ Gas. 1-Hexene and n-hexane were distilled in the presence of sodium slice and diphenyl ketone until a color of deep blue was observed. All the gas except for dry air were further purified by passing through columns packed by 4 A molecular sieve and low-valent MnOx. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Standard Schlenk technique and glove box filled with high purity N2 were used for all the procedures moisture and air should be avoided. To prepare TiO2 modified SiO2, about 10 g SiO2 was weighted and dried at 300 °C to remove the physically absorbed water. Then, Ti(OBu)4 was dissolved in n-hexane and impregnated with the dried SiO2 at 45 °C for 4 h, which would be dried at 80 °C for 4 h and transferred to a quartz fluidized bed with a diameter of 2 cm. Afterwards, the fluidized bed was blown into dry air of 600 mL/min and heated at a rate of 2 °C/min from room temperature to 600 °C, at which it was kept for 4 h and converted the Ti(OBu)4/SiO2 totally into TiO2-SiO2 support. The TiO2-SiO2 was then magnetically stirred with Cr(acac)3 and VO(acac)2 in the absence of any solvent for 4 h, which was calcinated at 600 °C in the quartz fluidized bed with the same procedures as those for TiO2-SiO2 preparation. The obtained CrOx/VOx/TiO2-SiO2 is denoted as CatSF. For comparison, 50 mL ethanol or deionized water was used to dissolve Cr(acac)3 and VO(acac)2 and impregnated with TiO2-SiO2. It was mixed by magnetic stirrer for 4 h and further dried at 120 °C to remove the solvent. The obtained flowing-free powder was calcinated by the procedure same as for CatSF. The catalysts prepared with ethanol and deionized water as solvent are named as CatE and CatW, respectively. The theoretical loading amount of Ti, Cr and V for all these catalysts is kept at 4.0, 0.5 and 0.5 wt%, respectively. 2.3 Ethylene polymerization Before polymerization, the steel reactor of 300 mL (Parr company) was heated at 100 °C for 30 min under dynamic vacuum, which was then cooled to 50 °C and flushed by N2. Then, a certain amount of TiBA and 130 mL n-hexane were added. While for copolymerization, 3 mL 1-hexene was injected at the same time. Afterwards, the reactor was heated to the polymerization temperature and pressured by C2H4, and a blade propeller worked at 560 rpm. Finally, catalyst suspension in 20 mL n-hexane was pressed into the reactor by N2 (P = 1.03 MPa). C2H4 was feed continuously to keep the pressure at 1.0 MPa, and its consumption rate was recorded online by a mass flowmeter (Brooks). After an hour of polymerization, the reactor was depressured, and the PE slurry was poured into HCl solution of ethanol, which was filtered and fully dried subsequently. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Specific surface area (SA), pore volume (PV) and pore size (PS) of support and catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption and desorption instrument (Micromeritics, 3Flex) at 77 K, where the SA was calculated by the BET method, while PV and PS were calculated by the BJH method. Element analysis of bulky Cr and V was carried out with an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific, iCAP 6000). Element analysis of surface metal was performed by an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX, Oxford, SwiftED 3000) coupled with a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Tescan, Mira Lms), in which the samples were sprayed by gold for 45 s. Catalyst acidity was tested with a chemisorption instrument (Micromeritics, AutoChem II 2920) by NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). 50 mg catalyst powder was weighted and dried at 300°C by He flow of 50 mL/min. After an hour, it was cooled to 50°C and saturated with 10% NH3/He (volume ratio) flow of 50 mL/min for an hour. Afterwards, the sample was flushed by He flow for an hour and NH3 desorption was then conducted at 10°C min−1 from 50 to 800°C. With BaSO4 being standard, diffuse reflectance (DR) Uv-vis spectra of these catalysts were measured in the range of 200–1000 nm by a Shimadzu Uv 2600 spectrophotometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory. A Raman spectrophotometer (Horiba Scientific, LabRAM HR Evolution) equipped with an Ar+ ion laser (785 nm) was used to record Raman spectra (200–1200 cm−1) with an exposure time of 65 s and an excitation power of 15 mW. 2.5 Polymer characterization The thermal properties of the PE products was treated by a differential scanning calorimeter (DSC, TA, Discovery 25). Firstly, the thermal history of PE samples (ca. 5 mg) was erased by heating up to 160 °C at a rate of 20 °C min−1 and cooling down to 30 °C at the same rate. Then, at a rate of 10 °C min−1, the sample was heated to 160 °C and cooled down to 30 °C. The tests were carried out at the atmosphere of N2, and the temperature and heat flow scale were calibrated by high purity indium. The average MW and MWD of PE products were measured by a high-temperature gel permeation chromatography (HT-GPC, Agilent, 1260 Infinity II). Two PLgel-Olexis columns were used, which were calibrated by a series of polystyrene standard samples with narrow polydispersity. 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene was stabilized by 0.5 wt% 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol and used to dissolve PE samples at 160℃ for 4 h. The measurement was conducted at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min−1 at 160℃. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties & chemical composition As shown in Table 1, the composite support TiO2/SiO2 is a typical mesoporous material with high specific surface area (SA) and pore volume (PV). Regarding to CatW, its PV and PD decreased almost 50% in relative to the support, which might mainly result from pore blockage caused by the loaded Cr and V. It seems the blockage occurred primarily at the pores with larger size, thus creating more pores with smaller size and preserving high SA. In addition, the water used as solvent for impregnation is featured by high surface tension, which tends to exacerbate pore collapse by surface condensation of hydroxyl group on one hand, and boost metal agglomeration on the other hand [39–41]. Pertaining to CatE, its SA and PV were reduced more or less, while PD even increased slightly, indicating Cr and V were apt to deposit at pores with smaller size [42]. Similar trends were also observed for CatSF, but with a larger reduction in SA and PV, and a greater increasement in PD. The ICP-OES results show that Cr and V were almost completely loaded at CatW, for which the bulky content was 0.49 and 0.48 wt%, respectively, while it was less efficient for the other two catalysts. It is likely that the utilization of water for CatW preparation can preserve more surface hydroxyl groups, which act as anchoring points for Cr and V species via esterification. While for CatSF, as Cr and V sources were only physically mixed with the support, more loss is likely due to volatilization [27]. We further characterized the surface abundance of the loaded metal by SEM-EDX (see Fig. 1), which shows that the signal from Cr and V is evenly dispersed on CatE. While for CatSF, though no solvent was employed, well dispersity similar to CatE was observed, which implies excellent mobility of Cr and V species during high temperature calcination. By contrast, the signal is scarce and intense over CatW. Given the higher bulky content of Cr and V in CatW, it indicates that Cr and V species inclined to aggregate and located deeply at the pores inaccessible by X-ray. As a matter of fact, because water is a poor solvent, it is difficult for both Cr(acac)3 and VO(acac)2 to diffuse into the pores of TiO2-SiO2 during impregnation. However, the introduced water was able to get the support surface fully hydroxylated. According to the results of McDaniel et al., this provided necessary conditions for Cr and V to migrate into the pores via dynamic hydrolysis under high temperature calcination [24,25]. As a comparison, the distribution of Cr and V complexes over the catalysts before high temperature calcination was analysed by SEM-EDX as well (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information), which shows that both complexes are evenly dispersed over CatE and CatW, while they are distributed in a concentrated way over CatSF. It indicates the significance of high temperature calcination for surface migration of Cr and V species. On the other hand, owing to the hydrolysis effect of water on Si-O-Ti linkage, loss of Ti sites is likely on CatW [43], which is reflected by its much more scattered signal of Ti. 3.2 Surface dispersity & acidity The Raman spectra of these catalysts is presented in Fig. 2. The bands around 1028 cm−1 and 980 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of VO and CrO, respectively [22,44,45]. The band at 854 cm−1 is typical for mono- and di-chromate on TiO2, which indicates the preference of CrOx over TiO2 [20]. The bands at ∼710 and ∼506 cm−1 are assigned to poly-vanadate species [46]. The bands at 380 cm−1 and 300 cm−1 are due to poly-chromate species [20]. The bands at 994, 697 and 284 cm−1 belonging to crystallized V2O5 are not detected for all the catalysts. However, a small band assigning to Cr2O3 crystalline at 547 cm−1 is detected on CatW [20], while it is absent on the other two catalysts, which indicates their better surface dispersity. We also tried to verify the presence of Cr2O3 crystalline over CatW by X-ray diffraction (XRD, see Figure S2 in Supporting Information), however, it was failed, which is probably owing to the lower sensitivity of XRD than Raman in detecting such species in low content [47]. When look into the Raman bands of Cr and V species, it is found the intensity is relatively weaker for CatW. It partially results from the scarcer Cr and V sites on CatW as observed by SEM-EDX. At the same time, overlapping of the bands due to Cr and V with those belonging to SiO2 (e.g. ∼430, 607 and 784 cm−1) also makes a contribution [44,47]. Careful examinations of the bands for CatE and CatSF show that those belonging to isolated Cr and V species have comparable intensity for the two catalysts, while those due to polymerized Cr and V species (i.e. ∼710, ∼506, 380 and 300 cm−1) are more distinct for CatSF. It is probably that, after physical mixing of the support with Cr and V sources, the initial dispersity of Cr and V is poor. Though Cr and V can migrate during the subsequent high temperature calcination, it is difficult to reach a dispersity as well as that for CatE, for which Cr and V can be carried by ethanol into the internal pores of the support and get a much better initial dispersity. However, the absence of the bands for crystallized Cr and V oxides implies the dispersity of Cr and V sites over CatSF is good. The DR Uv-vis spectra of the three catalysts are shown in Fig. 3. The dominant and broad band at ∼270 nm (Region 1 in Fig. 3) derived from ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) can be observed for all the three catalysts. It is mainly attributed to the electronic transitions from the 2p orbitals of O2- ligand to the 3d orbitals of highly dispersed Cr6+, V5+ and Ti4+ in isolated state [20,44,47]. For CatE and CatSF, a low-energy absorption tail with very weak intensity is detected at ∼360 nm (Region 2 in Fig. 3), which is due to LMCT transition between O2- and polymerized Cr6+, V5+ and Ti4+. While for CatW, this band is relatively stronger and shows as an absorption shoulder. Meanwhile, a weak and broad band at ∼600 nm (Region 3 in Fig. 3) can be identified for CatW, while it is undetectable for CatE and CatSF. This band is typically assigned to the d-d transition of Cr3+, V4+ and V3+, which is in line with the crystallized Cr3+ detected by Raman spectra [48,49]. It indicates that the dispersity of Cr and V over these catalysts follows the order as CatE ＞CatSF＞CatW. The surface acidity of the catalysts was measured by NH3-TPD (see Fig. 4). Regarding to CatE, it is clear that three strong peaks with comparable intensity can be identified at 100, 420 and 650 °C. The first one comes from the physically absorbed NH3, while the latter two are a consequence of NH3 desorption from the surface sites with moderate and strong acidity, respectively [50]. For CatSF, three peaks locating at the same temperature can be observed. However, the peak intensity, particularly for the strong acidic sites, becomes much weaker. While for CatW, the peak intensity decreases further, and the one at 650 °C even disappears. Therefore, the acidity follows a trend as CatE ＞CatSF＞CatW. The lower actual loading amount of Cr and V on CatSF in relative to CatE might account for the weaker acidity of the former to some extent [51]. More importantly, it was also proposed that better Cr and V dispersity was favorable to get higher acidity [52,53]. 3.3 C2H4 polymerization and polymer properties The results of C2H4 polymerization are listed in Table 2. At polymerization temperature (Tp) = 70 °C, high activity of 11.58 and 9.50 ×106 gPE·mol−1Cr·h−1 was achieved by CatSF and CatE, respectively, while it is much lower for CatW, which is about 6.78×106 gPE·mol−1Cr·h−1. This is in accordance with the higher and comparable site dispersity for CatSF and CatE and the higher content of crystallized sites in low-valence over CatW. As site aggregation is a deactivation mechanism for polyolefin catalysts, and low-valent metal center generated during high temperature calcination are disclosed to be inactive sites for the Phillips catalyst [1,32,54]. Furthermore, the higher activity of CatSF and CatE than that of CatW is also likely a consequence of the improved acidity of the former two, which is widely reported for C2H4 catalysis polymerization [55,56]. The weight-average molecular weight (Mw) of the PE produced by CatSF and CatE is also approximate, which is 9.5 and 10.9 ×105 g·mol−1, respectively. While that for CatW is as high as 13.6 ×105 g·mol−1. It implies the active site with poorer dispersity is apt to synthesize higher MW PE. In addition, the lower pore volume and narrower pore size of CatW might also retard its chain transfer process, thus leading to higher MW as well [57,58]. The MWD of the PE products is very broad as a whole, and it follows the trend as CatW ＞ CatSF ＞ CatE. As shown in Fig. 5, for the PE synthesized by CatSF and CatE, the curves of MWD reveal that the curve shape is analogous, which contains a low MW peak and an ultra-high MW shoulder, indicating their ability for the synthesis of UHMWPE/HDPE IRBs. While for CatW, the ultra-high MW shoulder grows into a distinct peak, thus endowing the curve with typical bimodal feature. The breadth of MWD is often used as an indicator for the heterogeneity of the active sites [59,60]. It is likely that the highly dispersed site on CatE is relatively homogeneous. While for CatSF, its site dispersity decreases more or less, and polymerized CrOx and VOx comes into being, which is responsible for the broader MWD of its PE products. With respect to CatW, its site dispersity becomes even broader, thus producing PE with the broadest MWD. When Tp increases to 80 °C, CatE and CatSF still show comparable activity much higher than that of CatW. The kinetics profiles of C2H4 polymerization are given in Fig. 6, which clearly show that all the catalysts display very stable activity, and the profiles for CatE and CatSF look analogously. The increased Tp boosted chain transfer process, which results in a MW reduction of the PE product. However, when compared with CatW, CatE and CatSF responded more sensitive to Tp. As a consequence, the MW of the PE synthesized by the latter two is approximate and much lower than that by the former one. This could be directly reflected by the MWD curves, for which the distinct bimodal character is preserved for the PE synthesized by CatW, while the ultra-high MW shoulder shrinks obviously for those produced by CatE and CatSF. Likewise, when H2 or 1-hexene was added, owing to the chain transfer agent role of both H2 and 1-hexene, MW reduction is observed as well, and the reduction degree is big and comparable for CatE and CatSF, while it is very faint for CatW. Moreover, the PE synthesized by CatE and CatSF also have MWD curves of similar shapes, which are obviously down-shifting towards the low MW region when compared with that produced by CatW (see Fig. 5 (C) and (D)). Furthermore, the melting curves of homopolymer and C2H4/1-hexene copolymer of these catalysts were tested and shown in Fig. 7. A peak nearby 134 °C is observed for the homopolymer, which is typical for HDPE. With regard to the copolymer, the melting temperature (Tm) decreases to 131.9 °C, indicating the formation of short chain branch (SCB) by incorporating an amount of 1-hexene, which can disturb the crystallization process and suppress melting temperature [61]. Again, the incorporation efficiency of 1-hexene is also higher and comparable for CatE and CatSF, which is reflected by the lower Tm of their copolymer locating at 129.9 and 129.1 °C, respectively. This can be reflected by the lamella thickness distribution of the copolymers as well (see Figure S3 in Supporting Information). As a whole, the active sites dispersing over CatE and CatSF are likely to have resembled structures and exhibit similar catalytic behaviors, which shows analogous kinetics and response to polymerization temperature, H2 transfer agent and 1-hexene comonomer in a similar way, thus displaying approximate activity and making polymers with comparable properties. 4 Conclusion In this work, given the surface mobility of Cr and V at high temperature [20,22,24,25,28], we explored solvent-free preparation of CrOx/VOx/TiO2-SiO2 bimetallic catalyst by dry mixing TiO2-SiO2 with Cr(acac)3/VO(acac)2 and subsequent calcination in dry air. For comparison, this catalyst was also prepared by conventional wet impregnation method with either water or ethanol as solvent. According to the results of ICP-OES, SEM-EDX and textural properties, it is found Cr and V was efficiently loaded onto the catalyst prepared with water as solvent (CatW), but the sites were more likely to migrate into catalyst bulk and probably aggregated into polymerized form, which caused severe pore blockage. When catalyst was prepared with ethanol as solvent (CatE) or by solvent-free process (CatSF), less amount of Cr and V was loaded, but the sites were more evenly dispersed. This is further verified by the Raman and DR Uv-vis spectra, which show that isolated Cr and V site was the main species on CatE, and more polymerized chromate and vanadate formed on the surface of CatSF, while this became more severe for CatW, on which crystallized sites were even detected. The results of NH3-TPD show the acidity follows the trends as CatE ＞ CatSF ＞ CatW, which is in accordance with the higher acidic nature of the site in better dispersity [52,53]. Moreover, the C2H4 polymerization results also show that CatE and CatSF behaved similarly in kinetics and displayed comparable activity, which is much higher than that of CatW. Bimodal UHMWPE/HDPE IRBS with very broad MWD could be synthesized by these catalysts. However, the active sites on CatE and CatSF also responded in an approximate way to polymerization temperature, H2 chain transfer agent and 1-hexene comonomer, and their PE products have lower MW, narrower MWD and more SCB when compared with those synthesized by CatW. As a whole, the similar catalytic behaviors and polymer properties indicate that CatE and CatSF possess active sites with almost the same structure, which is distinct with those belongs to CatW. This is further consistent with the well dispersity of the sites over CatE and CatSF and the poor dispersity of the sites over CatW. Therefore, this work proves that solvent-free preparation of CrOx/VOx/TiO2-SiO2 is a workable way to obtain well-dispersed Cr and V sites with high performance for C2H4 polymerization. More importantly, it also offers an alternative method to simplifies the catalyst preparation process and avoids the generation of liquid waste containing environmental harmful Cr and V. coredata.dc:description: CrOx/VOx/TiO2-SiO2 was prepared via solvent-free and conventional wet-impregnation process with ethanol as solvent. The results of ICP-OES, N2 adsorption-desorption, SEM-EDX, Raman and DR-Uv-vis spectra indicate that well-dispersed Cr and V sites in isolated state were the main species. Bimodal ultra-high molecular weight polyethylene/high-density polyethylene in-reactor blends (UHMWPE/HDPE IRBs) could be synthesized with polymerization activity ＞ 1×107 gPE·mol−1Cr·h−1. Moreover, the two catalysts displayed similar catalytic behaviors in temperature sensitivity, H2 response and 1-hexene copolymerization efficiency, and their polymer products also show comparable molecular weight and molecular weight distribution, which implies analogous structures of their well-dispersed active sites. By contrast, the catalyst prepared by wet-impregnation process with water as solvent exhibited poor dispersity, which is reflected by its much lower activity and very different catalytic behaviors and polymer properties when compared with the well-dispersed catalysts. Therefore, the economic and green solvent-free process is promising for preparing highly-active CrOx/VOx/TiO2-SiO2.
